did.unittitle: The Inquiry Papers

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Correspondence, organizational records, reports containing historical and statistical material, maps, and other papers of The Inquiry, a group of experts assembled at the request of President Wilson to collect and collate data in preparation for a peace conference following World War I. Members of The Inquiry included Edward House, Sidney Mezes, Isaiah Bowman, Charles Seymour, David H. Miller, Walter Lippmann, James T. Shotwell, and Clive Day.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The Inquiry Papers (MS 8). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Part of the collection was transferred from House Papers MS 466, and the remainder was the gift of the American Geographic Society in 1961.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in six series and oversized: I. Correspondence, 1918-1919, II. Records Regarding Administrative Matters, 1917-1919, undated, III. Reports and Studies, 1917-1920, undated, IV. Abstracts, Precis, Notes, 1902-1918, undated, V. Printed Materials, 1913-1927, undated, VI. Photographs and Maps, 1915-1918, undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: As was noted by Stephen Helton in his introduction to the National Archives' Records of the American Commission to Negotiate Peace (Preliminary Inventories, No. 89; Washington: 1955), in the fall of 1917, following the declaration of war against Germany,

blockquote.p: Col. E. M. House, at the request of President Wilson, began to assemble in New York a group of experts to collect and collate data on geographical, ethnological, historical, economic, and political problems of Europe and other areas of the world in preparation for the peace conference, which should follow World War I. This group of experts, called 'The Inquiry,' was under the direction first of Sidney E. Mezes and later of Isaiah Bowman. At the time of its greatest development it consisted of 18 divisions, 11 of which dealt with special problems of particular areas or regions. Its staff was made up largely of professors recruited from American universities and colleges. The Inquiry made a number of investigations; …and in 1918 it assembled a large quantity of material on national boundaries. In December 1918 The Inquiry ceased to be an independent body and was absorbed into the Division of Territorial, Economic, and Political Intelligence of the American Commission to Negotiate Peace.*

scopecontent.p: The Yale Inquiry Papers are an amalgamation of two separate collections: (a) a relatively small amount of material, dealing directly with The Inquiry, which Charles Seymour (the first curator of the House Collection) assembled from amongst his own papers and those of Colonel House and Clive Day and rearranged under an artificial "Inquiry" subheading; and (b) the much larger set of bona fide Inquiry "office records," left originally under the care of the American Geographical Society (The Inquiry's first "home") which were given to the Yale Library in 1961 in honor of President Seymour's 75th birthday.

The bulk of The Inquiry's records are housed in the National Archives, where they form part of Record Group 256 ("Records of the American Commission to Negotiate Peace"), whose contents are described in the Preliminary Inventory list [No. 89] mentioned above. The Yale Inquiry Papers consist to a considerable extent of duplicate material (roughly 12 cubic feet of material compared to 85 cubic feet housed in the National Archives); and even the strongest categories (Special Reports and Studies and Maps) are far from complete.
The Yale Inquiry Papers are arranged in six major series, which are described in greater detail in the pages that follow:
Series I. General Correspondence. (2 boxes) Primarily 'inter-office' correspondence from (or to) Clive Day and Charles Seymour, (1918-1919).

Series II. Records Regarding Administrative Matters. (1 box) The most significant items are Douglas Johnson's letters describing his special mission to England and France in the spring of 1918; and various "progress reports" from Sidney Mezes, Isaiah Bowman, and David Hunter Miller to Colonel House.

Series III. Reports and Studies. (23 boxes) The bulk of these reports deal with specific problems (and sub-divisions) of the Austro-Hungarian and Ottoman Empires; the Balkans; Alsace-Lorraine; the Adriatic question; Poland; India, and German colonies in Africa. (An "Index of Authors" is appended.)
Series IV. Abstracts, Precis, Notes. (5 boxes) Various notes and miscellaneous research materials used primarily by Charles Seymour and Clive Day in their studies on Austria-Hungary and the Balkans.
Series V. Printed Materials. (1 box) Ten miscellaneous items.

* See also Lawrence Gelfand, The Inquiry: American Preparations for Peace, 1917-1919 [New Haven: 1963]; and Harold B. Whitemen (ed.), Charles Seymour's Letters from the Paris Peace Conference [New Haven: 1965]. Much additional information will undoubtedly emerge from Arthur Walworth's forthcoming study on American diplomacy at the peace conference; volumes VI and VII of Arthur Link's biography of Woodrow Wilson; the pertinent volumes of The Papers of Woodrow Wilson , and Charles Neu's projected full scale biography of Colonel House.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains letters to and from certain members of The Inquiry staff (primarily Clive Day and Charles Seymour, but also Sidney E. Mezes, Isaiah Bowman, David Hunter Miller, and a few others), as well as directives from State Department officials intimately connected with the work of The Inquiry (Robert Lansing, Frank L. Polk, Gordon Auchincloss).

Series I is subdivided as follows (individual folders are arranged alphabetically by correspondent): (a) Letters to or from Clive Day; (b) Letters to or from Charles Seymour; (c) Letters to or from Isaiah Bowman; (d) Letters to or from Sidney E. Mezes; (e) Letters to or from Gordon Auchincloss; (f) Miscellaneous letters.
The number in parentheses following each correspondent's name records the number of documents in the folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports are arranged alphabetically under principal geographical or topical categories (e.g. "Austria-Hungary;" "Zionism"): these categories contain one or more entries, each entry comprising a single report.
Some cross-referencing will be found -- primarily with regard to Reports dealing with more than one territorial area.*
To avoid confusion (and a proliferation of entries) certain sets of statistical tables, etc., have been grouped together under single headings.

Individual [folder] entries are arranged as follows: (1) the full title of the Report (when known), or a representative description (if the title page is missing); (2) author's name; (3) date of completion of Report (or of its reception at The Inquiry's headquarters); (4) total number of pages, including appendices. (Wherever needed, additional descriptive information has been provided in a note.)
Unless otherwise noted, Reports are in typescript (ribbon or carbon copies).
The list of Reports is supplemented by an Index of Authors (appended).
* Material regarding the following countries can be found under Boundary Disputes:
Argentina
Bolivia
Chile
Colombia
Ecuador
Honduras
Nicaragua
Peru
Uruguay
Venezuela

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV contains material compiled by (or for) individual Inquiry staff members (primarily Charles Seymour and Clive Day) as aids in preparation of some of the Reports found in Series III.

Series IV has been subdivided into four main categories, with entries arranged alphabetically within each category: (a) Miscellaneous Statistical Tables; (b) Abstracts of Miscellaneous Area Studies; (c) Miscellaneous Research Notes; (d) Abstracts, Precis, Translations (of articles, speeches, etc., drawn from outside sources).
